NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? There were about 12 homes in our district where we visited back and forth. How many of these were bachelor's homes? No bachelor homes.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Usually on Sunday following Church, or sometimes during the week, particularly if someone was ill or in need of other help.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On Sunday mostly.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? People never invited anyone in the early days. People just called in and accepted food or other things as the family were able to supply. People were always pleased to see each other and never worried about anything as formal as an invitation. What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually visited in the morning - had dinner with the family and left for home about 4 p.m. in the afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, a meal was always set for visitors if the proper time presented itself. It was quite customary that people stay for dinner, with friends or relatives.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) As mentioned above everyone was so pleased when visitors came no thought was ever given to whether or not they would stay for a meal - it was just done automatically and without invitation. We ate whatever the family of the house was going to eat - no extras were provided in any way.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? None. If you did not have time to eat a meal with the family - no other refreshment was served.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? When the children of the family were all small they all went with their folks, but as we grew older we usually visited families who had grown up children our own age and less went out separately.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to sew a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes we did, and they were usually a good excuse for the community to get together and although we worked hard there was much fun and good fellowship.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. In the winter months we had "bees" mostly attended by women who would card and teaze wool and slice feathers for making of cushions, rugs, etc. Sometimes men would attend and would be employed at plucking of the geese. Usually a lunch of bread, buns, butter, and coffee was served. Of course we had "building bees" and helped each other in building of houses, barns, etc., along the same lines, the work here being done mostly by men and the women would supply the lunch.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. No, not for our particular family. We were of Baptist Church faith which did not allow us to take part in very many parties etc., just purely socials with perhaps singing and children's games.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? As mentioned above most of our visiting was done on Sunday and we tried to visit a different family each Sunday.

PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

RECREATIONAL VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? There were about 12 houses in our district where we visited back and forth.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? No bachelor's homes.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Usually on Sunday following Church, or sometimes during the week, particularly if someone was ill or in need of other help.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On Sunday mostly.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was not visiting done without an invitation? People never invited anyone in the early days. People just called in and accepted food or other things as the family were able to supply. People were always pleased to see each other and never worried about anything so formal as an invitation the afternoon, etc.? Usually visited in the morning - had dinner with the family and left for home about 4 p.m. In the afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, a meal was always set for visitors if the proper time presented itself. It was quite customary that people stay for dinner, with friends or relatives.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to take "proluck" used, or was some other expression common?) It was mentioned above everyone was so pleased when visitors came no thought was ever given to whether or not they would stay for a meal. It was just done automatically.

Did you ever have "house parties," or other such activity? Yes we did, and they were usually a good excuse for the community to get together and although we worried hard there was much fun and good fellowship among the guests.

Tell us how you spent your free time and how often they occurred. In the winter months we had fires, what we now call "fire parties." We would card and tease wool and make festivities for ourselves, mostly attended by women who would attend and would be employed at spinning or knitting, etc. Usually a lunch of bread, bun, butter, and coffee was served.

Of course, we had "building bees" and helped each other in building of houses, barns, etc., along the same lines; the work here being done mostly by men and the women would just purely socialize with perhaps singing and children's games.

In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, supply the lunch of Baptist Church faith which this not allow us to take part in very many parties etc., drives or dancing in homes? Describe. No, not for our particular family. We were just purely socialize with perhaps singing and children's games.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? As mentioned above most of our visiting was done on Sunday and we tried to visit a different family each Sunday.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

We had our Sunday School Christmas Tree in the school house, and had our picnics in the school grounds.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe. All of our social life emanated from our Church (Baptist) but the functions of necessity had to be held in the school building.

9. When was your first community hall built? never had one while we lived at Edenwold.

What material was it made of? - How large was it? -

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? -

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes, we would all go.

How were babies and small children provided for?
They were just put to bed on cots, beds, tables, or anything that was handy.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?
sheltered and fed in sod or log built stables

11. What card games were popular in the early days?
pedro, poker, whist, cribbage and black-jack

Was there card playing for a prize? No - never gave prizes for anything in the early years - the honor was sufficient.

What dances were popular?
Quadrilles mostly, although we had polkas, two-steps and the waltz

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. There was no actual disagreement, but we were not allowed to dance because of our Baptist Faith. Later years when Lutherans began to settle there they had dances but we were not allowed to attend them.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. In our particular community a lot of people frowned on card playing because practically all the families were of Baptist Faith and this religion would not allow the playing of card games.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? There was nothing at all like this in my day. We were all poor pioneers and could not be bothered with so called "swank" nor did we have the money to carry it out.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes, and quite a popular affair. Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. If the particular couple were well liked they were always "chivareed". The families would all go - take them gifts and supply the lunch, and then we would wind up with a dance in their new home (usually built by the people of the community).

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable. Usually the week prior to Christmas we visited around all during that week. The old folks would sit around and tell ghost stories or other stories which had been told to them when they were growing up "in the old land". The young people would play games at these gatherings and possibly sing some of the hymns and songs from the "old land".

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? The first organization we had of any kind in our community was a syndicate for a threshing machine (Minneapolis-Moline) by the man. Give the date and reason for it being organized. It was organized to purchase the Threshing machine for threshing and grinding wheat for flour, whole wheat, grits, chop and feed. There was a chooper with the threshing machine which was operated by 6 horses going round in a circle turning a machine with long 12 foot arms on it. A man stood in the middle with a whip and kept the horses going 'round. This turned the chopping machine.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Ball, pussy wants a corner, skipping rope, made kites out of paper, drop the handkerchief, and we had a swing made by our parents, and we loved to play school and house, hide and go seek, blind man's buff, and touch wood

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Same as the boys - played together well.

22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
   Sledding mostly in the winter months
   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? We would play the games we got for Christmas; what are you taking to the farm; string and a ring; button-button; and card games.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. The very small children always played games, but as soon as we were old enough to do our share of the work, we had to mix our work with our pleasure.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.
   When I was a child we spent many hours catching gophers and trying to tame squirrels. We made daisy chains and located bird nests but never destroyed anything. When there was wild fruit to be picked we did this - saskatoons, cherries, strawberries, raspberries and gooseberries.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?
   Give year and month if possible. about 1892

26. Who organized it? Our Baptist Church Sunday School.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?
   It was organized for the whole community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? It was the first one I can remember
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? Possibly from the time we settled there in 1886.

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?
   mostly races and a ball game

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Each family would take what they could for food; everything was spread on white table cloths on the grass in a long row, and everyone would sit down together and eat. There were no groups or cliques of people going off on their own to eat in those days.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
   Eggs, green onions, various fancy breads & we milk and coffee

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
   The picnic usually started immediately following the Sunday morning Church Service and last through till about 4 in the afternoon when people had to return to their homes to attend the livestock etc.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

Sledding mostly in the winter months. Games were played indoors in winter - card games such as marbles, "whist," "whack-a-mole," or other games. We would play the games we got for Christmas; what are you talking to the family? string and a ring; button-button; did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

The younger people played the games, but the older people not very much.

In the snow, we made daisy chains and located wind nests but often didn't get anything; there was wild fruit to be picked; we did this - melon, cherries, strawberries, raspberries and gooseberries.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Oliver year and month if possible; about 1922

26. Who organized it? Our Baptist Church Sunday School.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? It was organized for the whole community.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? (Correctly from the time we settled there in 1886.)

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Mostly races and a ball game.

Each family would take what they could for food; everything was spread on white table cloths on the grass in a long row, and everyone would sit down together and eat. There were no crowds or cliques of people going off on their own to eat in those days.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Waste bread, butter, and milk.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? The picnic usually started immediately following the Sunday morning Church Service and lasted through until about 4 in the afternoon when people had to return to their homes to attend the livestock etc.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

I think the feature of these picnics which I remember as being outstanding is the companionship and sociability of the people. They would always be talking and laughing and sharing each other's sorrows and joys. Everyone was reasonably poor and in this regard there could be no class distinction. Everyone was truly interested in each other's welfare.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Our picnics were always organized by the Church Sunday School and were always a community effort.

I believe I have stated this change in my answer to question number 33.

The younger children of the families were really the only ones who had much time for recreation, and of course they just played the usual children's games mentioned in a previous question.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

The Bibles was the only book brought to this country by my folks.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? They too, just brought the Bible. What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

No, we did not—never had the money to do so.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? None that I know of.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes in later years. When was it begun? Don't recall.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? We only had about a dozen books and were not allowed to take them home. Our folks could not read the English language, and it was only when the school children arrived at the age when they could read English could we make use of these books.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? No, they could not read English.

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

We used to have a lot of box socials in connection with the dances when I was old enough to attend. The young girls of the community would make a box and fill it as best she could with a tempting lunch. The young men would gather together and these boxes would be auctioned off. The man making the purchase would eat the lunch with the girl who supplied it and they would be partners for the evening.

On occasion the whole community would enter into a "spelling Bee" - there would be no prize given, but the honor was very acceptable.
